She was very understanding and nice about the situation and I liked that she didn't hover over me as if I'd take off running.  For this reason (and many others) Fireside is one of my favorite bars.
author: Dianne d.

description:
We decided to meet here because of its physical proximity to a friends party and didn't have any idea what it would be like.  I was pleasantly surprised from the minute I walked in and Fireside is now on my list of good bars.

Friendly, charming bartender named Mario who knows how to pour!  Very comfortable room and comfortable seating.  Good selection of liqour.

Also, I really liked the crowd.  I have no stereotype to describe them so I will try "regular people".  Okay, thats weak...      but thats all I am coming up with (did I mention I am still recovering from NYE?).  Go have a drink at the Fireside and see for yourself.
author: lisa g.

description: This quiet, low-profile watering hole is much appreciated in a neighborhood sporting few bars or lounges.  The cozy fireplace gives this place a relaxed vibe.  No credit cards though.
author: Rick H.

description:
Hey Fireside...  I understand the attitude.  You got two scruffy looking people, just coming off from work and the gym, trying to grab a quick drink from your establishment.  Why, take us seriously?

*Sniff sniff*... yeah that's me.  What, you don't like my cologne?  It's called Ode de Man.  All naturale.

Hey, I like the ambience here.  You got the large windows overlooking Judah.  Cozy fireplace.  Nice couch bitch... why don't I stretch out!

It's cool man... I already have bartender friends.
author: Sam T.

description:
How many bartenders does it take to open a bottle of wine? 

One.

And 4 other patrons who sit at the bar.

I'm not sure if the bartender had just dipped her hands in olive oil or she didn't dip her screw properly into the cork. But my pals and I ordered some wine and it took 10 minutes to open the bottle.  Oh well, we all have out bad days, or slippery nights.

Wine incident aside-the darkness, fireplace, comfy semicircle couch, and jukebox make for cool neighborhood bar. It's a great place to go when Yancy's turns into a frat party.
author: Jonny M.

description:
Many eateries I frequent are within two blocks of this place, so I'm always passing by and "meaning" to stop in for a drink sometime.
Always looks cozy.
It was very busy on this particular friday night.  
For me it can actually add to the enjoyment if.....
...the crowd is cool.
yes.
...we're comfortable with wherever we happen to be posted...
...scored a seat in front of the fireplace...
yes. (if the crowd is cool, it doesn't matter where you post up, right?)
...the bartenders are on top of their game...
...courteous, knowledgable, friendly, generous...
yes.
The drink has depth...(selection and pour, see above)
yes.
Good music....
....music is subjective...get your mp3 on...
yes.
Easy recipe huh?
Funny how many bars in SF can't get it right, and don't even warrant a mention.
We'll be back.
yes.
author: Barry A.

description:
Thanks for letting me barf in your bathroom in the middle of the day after a night of drinking even though you didn't know about it.

Thanks for the pretty tasty Bloody Mary for only $5 from the friendly bartender after I barfed and felt much better.

Thanks for being a cozy and fun place to visit on an evening after eating sushi around the corner at Ebisu.

No thanks for the crazy loud obnoxious regulars who plant themselves at the bar on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Audrey K.

description:
Neighborhood bar on Irving Street that caters to a mix of locals, USF/UCSF students, and professional drinkers. There are fewer pros than at a true dive bar, though they still hold court during the day. One gave me a peptalk/feedback on a date while she was off to the restroom. Some people might not trust a barfly who says your date is into you, but I'm not one of those people.

They do have a fireplace, and their bartenders are friendly in a bartender way, not in a "Welcome to Applebees, would you like to try our Chocolate Chip Mocha-tinis?" sort of way. The last time I was there, the bartender was friendly in a "I think your date needs a free drink" way. He was right about that. My date DID need a free drink.
author: Timothy O.

description:
This is hands-down my favorite bar in the neighborhood, and maybe the city. Ok, so it's convenient to my apartment, so it's got a leg up there due to location, but there are many bars in my neighborhood that I don't even consider. I look forward to the Fireside, which has to say something. The bartenders are almost all cool and laid back- Mario is the BEST, absolute best, particularly because he gave me shit for insulting (somewhat accidentally) the bar (after my comment he came up to my boyfriend and asked, "Does she [jerking thumb towards me] want another drink?"

Classic. Awesome. He served me again, thankfully.

This bar has been in the neighborhood for ages. I met a regular who has been drinking there for 30 years. THAT is the mark of a good bar.

And then there are the drinks. Good selection of beer. Great cocktails. Somewhat crappy wine, but this isn't a place where you go to get fine wine. This is a mellow-with-your-friends, watch-the-game type of place, or stumble-in-for-last-call-at-midnight type of place. If you don't know what either of those mean, this isn't the place for you.

OH! I almost forgot- this bar is DOG FRIENDLY (and I'm not talking about people). Bring a leash, they have biscuits for Fido.
author: Bethany P.

description:
I don't really show up here too often now that Lisa isn't around but it remains one of the only legitimate bar options in the inner sunset. 

Mario is what you want in a day time bartender. No frills. Draws a regular guy sorta crowd. 

There are a couple of younger guys running things at night. I've been ignored by the taller one on one occasion when he decided to pay attention to a group of giggly girls instead of me. Your loss pal. Bartenders tend to tip better than girls barely old enough to enter a bar and you probably had to make them a shit load of cosmo's to get a dollar from them. All you needed to pour me was a shot of Fernet and I would have taken care of you. I walked out. It's all good, I've done the same thing myself on occasion. I hope you at least got some action for my troubles. 

Let's face it, the couches in front of the roaring fireplace is a big draw. I've brought three different girls here and they all warmed up to the place and since I brought them there, me as well. You're all right Fireside!
author: lazslo t.

description:
I don't drink in my own neighborhood too often - mostly because of my friends who insist upon living far away from me, selfish people that they are - but this is my go-to Sunset spot.

Not too crowded, average drink prices (insofar as I know), quiet enough to talk.

The first time I came here, ages and ages ago, they were playing Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends on the TV.  EPIC WIN.  Bloo is my hero. 

They were also playing Flogging Molly on the jukebox.  I may get hurt for this, but EPIC FAIL.  (I hate Flogging Molly with a fiery passion usually reserved for people who do bad things to innocent children.  Sorry.  It can't be helped.)

Regardless - I like it.  It has all the requirements for clandestine meetings - the kind that hold more signifigance after the fact then they do at the time - dark, a little dingy, warm (er, you know...that whole fireplace thing), and seating that manages to seem private.

The next time I have a bad idea that seems so, so good at the time, I will definitely take it here.
author: Jennie K.

description:
A favorite neighborhood watering hole of mine! 

WHEN to come here?
1. After a long day at work (a Tuesday PM visit was the height of my stressful work days!)
2. When I just want to grab a drink, sit with it, chat up the bartender and zone out
3. Meet up with friends before heading out for the night
4. Bring a date here to arrhm! "suss" him out 
5. If you're curious to see how guys cruise girls and vice versa

WHAT'S to love?
1. The crowd is diverse
2. The place has an edge to it (especially the glass cube walls)
3. The music juke box is always fun to fiddle with
4. The drinks are well priced and cheap
5. The bartenders are friendly and folks are laid back, non-pretentious and out to have a good time
6. The place is noisy but not loud enough that you cannot hear each other talk
7. No long wait for your drink
8. They take credit cards and cash

Anything AMISS?
1. A pool table would be nice :)

Head on over to the Fireside and get warmed up, y'all!
author: Amit S.

description: it's pretty cozy here, parking is easy when you go late at night.  The crowd is not as noisy as it as at Yancy's. I've been here about 3 times, but the crowd seems to be older. the crowds on Saturday are prob. better.  but this is still a good place to just chill with friends.
author: Belinda C.

description: Kind bartender, and dogs allowed. 5 dollar beer, oookkk. BUT, after and hour or so of the dark room, alcoholic regulars, and Phil Collins "Another Day in Paradise" and similar songs playing, I left feeling like crying. Youngest person in the bar, but felt worried I was getting involved in the fast track to cirrhosis club. :(
author: Ali G.

description:
I really like bars with a digital jukebox. I'll drop 20 dollars or more for the awesome feeling of power I get from being GOD OF THE JUKEBOX. The other mortals tend to be treated to a post punk medley that only a person with refined musical tastes would appreciate. I like to think I am a new testament style god of the jukebox though, forgiving and paternal.

I've been having trouble finding a decent bar near work. I like it, but when I come there is never anyone there. Maybe because I am going on Monday night? Yes, that must be it.
author: Erin G.

description:
Went here last night, and I like it.  It was a Wednesday night, around 11p, and it was comfortably crowded.  The bartender (a pretty blond woman) was super cool.  The crowd was late-20s, mid-30s, good-looking, hip-yuppie (a group that I could see both in the marina or in the mission), social without being too aggressive.  The music (from a jukebox) is a wee-bit too loud, but I was still able to chat with my buddy.  Overall, I like it.  I might be back tomorrow.

*** Update:  I've been here many times since first writing this review, and I just want to say that I still really like this place.  And, perfect for winter, they make very nice hot toddies.  Not too strong, not too sweet.
author: S J.

description: Imagine yourself drinking beer from an Ikea showroom placed inside a dark divey bar. The term "lounge" is being used quite loosely but Hey, they got Chimay on tap that gets an A-OK out of me. Also their JukeBox is pretty sweet when the bartender isn't regulating on the songs.
author: R J.

description:
Now, I can't compare because I didn't know this bar before it's current incarnation.  So I feel no ill-will or vengeful-nostalgia.  I've been hitting this bar since I moved to the area late last year, and I'm only disappointed when it gets run over by ex-frat-boys.  But that's nobody's fault but their mothers'...
Great drinks, great prices, great staff.  Super personable, and the fire's always stoked when Lisa's on.  And they put it within walking distance!  How nice of them!
author: Billy M.

description:
I live across the street from this little place...literally.  I walk out my door, cross the street and pass the MUNI stop and POOF! I am there.  Pass it all the time and never go in because of the cloud of smoke that lingers at the front door from displaced nicotine fiends.  Last resort on a Tuesday night after the bar across the street was closed.  
Nice bartender, good music - a bit loud on a Tuesday night, and $5 beer.  Cash only so leave the plastic at home (I was totally unprepared and my roomie covered me).  Art for sale on the walls from local artists - some very nice but pricey pieces (one sold for $1300).  
Would I go back? Sure.  As long as my roomie is paying ;)
author: Amireh G.

description:
Just a scone's throw away from Tart to Tart, walk in through their stable doors and into a hip place to go after your just desserts for a cocktail in a city lounge atmosphere without having to drive downtown.

The seating by the fire is a great way to thaw off (if you can score a spot!)  but don't expect to get any audible chatting done, as the loud music plus the din of the crowd packed in such a small space will drown out the story you were waiting all day to tell your friends.  Better to save it for later.
author: Marjorie B.

description: Great low-key non-crowded joint to hang out with some friends.  Great bar staff, nice space, cheap drinks, and the fireplace is nice on cold nights (though don't sit too close or you leave this bar medium-well.)  They're also cool about you bringing in food from some of the places around here, to the point of keeping a binder of local menus behind the counter.
author: Joshua W.

description: Definitely hit or miss depending on the bartender. I haven't really come around enough to figure out which nights are the best yet. Not sure how likely that is either when this is only my casual local bar. Aw well, drinks aren't terribly expensive and I can usually get a spot to sit with a few friends.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Just check out The Fireside yesterday as I was on a 'Sunday Bloody Sunday' tour of Irving St. I little disappointing to say the least. Not The Fireside, the Irving Bloody Tour.

 The Fireside however was still a stop worth taking. It's a very low-key, locals bar with no frills. It's fairly small, yet comfortable. There was some table seating and a few lounge booths situated around the fireplace, though you'll find most of the clientle here kickin' it at the bar, shootin' the shit with the bartender.

 Best thing about this bar worth noting; DOGS! Yes, pooches are welcome. Gotta love that.
author: alexa c.

description: Cool loungy bar with a great juke box!! Not too loud so you can still have a conversation, which I love. Great wine selection! Def will be back to chill.
author: Amber F.

description:
Fireside was a nice place to stop after a late dinner in the neighborhood. It has a nice atmosphere, the sofas and fireplace are a really nice touch. The bartender that night was very friendly and laid back, and the crowd was small and decent (on a Sunday night). Someone even brought their (very friendly) dog inside and sat at the bar.

I didn't get to peruse the jukebox for its music, but it was a geeky delight to find that the jukebox is also a Wi-fi access point! I happened to have my laptop with me and I was browsing the web while drinking Chimay. Classy, I tell you.
author: Courtney P.

description:
If I were more of a bar connoiseur, Fireside would be my favorite bar ever. But as I'm not - I won't go all out on the stars. 
It's small but jammed w/seating, so I'm sure even on a crowded evening you'll get to cool your feet. They had lots of bottles on the shelves and 5-6 beers on tap. Looks like a bar to me!
Mario & sundry managment, as well as the regular oldtimers (they looked well practiced at hanging at the bar at 1pm) are obviously chill good people, having let random folks use their establishment for a Saturday potluck.  
We made bar history today, running a chocolate fondue fountain for the first time in the Fireside Bar. 
Doubt they'll ever get the coolest for now European DJ to spin there,  but if you want to find that Cheers-like-regular-bar-destination - check Fireside out.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Upon walking in, I felt like I was entering the movie set of Reality Bites, that Mazzy Star's haunting voice in "Fade into You" would then cloud the room and a Johnny Depp look alike with a leather jacket and flannel plaid tied around his waist would turn to me and grin, take a shot...cheers.  I pretty much killed the moment that night.  Had my Hello Kitty scrubs on and surprisingly they were playing Aqua Teen Hunger Force.  Maybe the bar gods knew I just turned 21 and wouldn't grant me the right of passage.

Anyways, this is the place where I discovered I liked Sierra Nevadas.  To turn 21 on a Monday night and not get out of work until 11:30pm was a major downer.  I ordered my first drink, a Guiness.  Spat!  That shit is so nasty, like coffee that has been sitting there for days.  Me and the rest of the people I work with got free beers, courtesy of moi.  Fat tires, Sierra Nevadas, Stella Artois galore...and 10 pounds of a ring of flubber that I am desperately trying to shed!! (if possible).  But this place was very cozy and catering to me and my coworker's loudness and howling on that Monday night.  Aside from the slobber-faced couple across the room, the environment was great.  The fireplace, illuminated.  Just right.  The best dive bar I've been to ever since.
author: Joellene B.

description:
I came here on a Friday night. 

It's a cozy (it could probably fit 40-50 people comfortably), trendy bar. 

It was a little noisy and dark, so you can't expect to have an "let's get to know each other over coffee" type date here because you'd probably have to speak up (unless you're snuggling on the couch in front of the fireplace). 

The dark lighting works well with the fireplace for ambiance. Not to mention it's relatively clean and doesn't have sticky surfaces from spilled drinks that some bars have. 

The highlight was when we ordered 6 car bombs/jager bombs and it came out to be relatively cheap at ~$5-6 a drink. The bartender/owner followed up by asking "who paid for this round?" It was me, and so he handed me a free shot and took a shot with me. That's some sweet customer service. Just because of that, I'm planning to come back.

Some things to pay heed to if coming here: Cash only and beer pints were $5.

All in all, good customer service, reasonably priced drinks, clean and relaxed ambiance makes Fireside a place worth visiting.
author: P M.

description:
+1 for no cover and affordable prices

+1 for a cool jukebox/free WiFi deal

+1 for the fireplace and lack of pretentiousness or diveyness

-1 for the loudness - the music was fine, but the amount of people in this echo chamber made it tough for conversation, even for just 2 of us

-1 for the TVs playing sports - I thought a bunch of the reviews said they *didn't* have this??
author: Nate L.

description: This bar is awesome!!! The people are very kind and friendly! The bar tender Mario is so cool and very welcoming!!! Love this place!!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Look, most of the bad reviews of Fireside are because of personal taste. Fireside is a locals bar where the bartenders know your name and know what you drink. If you make a habit of coming in here the bartenders will end up comping you drinks. I live in the inner sunset to avoid douche bars and foofoo people. Most of the people at Fireside are nice locals. 

This bar is not designed for a large group of people and thats a good thing. If you have a large group then go to Yancys down the street. This place is perfect for you and a couple of friends to go to hang out, have a couple of drinks and enjoy some good music. Fireside is my favorite bar in the city. 

In response to J.C.'s review: "no dance floor, no blue moon on tap".
dude, there is not enough room in this place for a dance floor and if you are looking to dance then head to the Mission...and no Blue Moon on tap??? You have no taste in beer. Order a Lagunitas IPA on tap or a Black Butte Porter on tap. You would order a Blue Moon at Toronado wouldn't you?
author: crimson w.

description: Really like this place, one of my favorites in The City. Good spot just to chill. Superfriendly bartender.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Nice people. Never crowded. Warm fire. 
The best part is that they allow dogs!

I really enjoy spending time at this place. Blame Poe T for taking me here.

Try to go on nights when the female bartender is working. The male is slow and doesnt make drinks very well.
author: Brando Calrissian ..

description:
Cozy. 

Indeed. I had many an argument with my ex in every place around this whole damn neighborhood. Still, when we came to Fireside, somehow, that was all irrelevant. It was right by the Judah stop. Even if we were coming back from a rainy day downtown, and it was across the street, it seemed to beckon. 

I guess you heed the call and understand the place you're at for you've gone there for a reason and you stay for the reasons you've accepted. Good tap. And fire. Yes.
author: Roy M.

description: Meh. Yes, there is a fireplace in the bar. Which is great theoretically, but, it always seems like every time I go in there the door is open and it's freezing. Not exactly the cozy ambiance one would expect in a bar called The Fireside. Decent beer selection. Random otherwise.
author: andrea l.

description:
I like going there for a drink after work.

Hey, it's better than yancy's.
author: Ruth R.

description:
Love it.  Cash only, but otherwise no down side.  
One of the few places in the Inner Sunset that resonates w/ my "dress shoe" persona
author: Robby T.

description:
Deep conversations- y'know, the ones where you get that chance to talk with your friends about all those deep, fascinating epiphanis about life? fireside seems to be some crazy cosmic nexus where this seems to happen all the time- at least to me.

oh no less than the last few times i've been there, I've figured out a.) I should break up with the girl I was dating for 5 years b.) there's more to life than just (fill in verb/adverb here) and c.) if you eat naan n curry, there's no going back from smelling like naan n curry all night...

oh, the bar? chill, relaxed, and they make a damn strong gimlet
author: Tim V.

description:
Even with the paint job and the new furniture this place still has a feel of The Wishing Well.  Walking by anytime of the afternoon seeing the same gin-blossomed blokes in there hiding from the light of day. 

I did try to see it from another angle however.   I went  there a couple of weeks ago on my 35th birthday, my friend and I were in a whole other age category.  Twenty-somethings doesn't even start to describe the other patrons....I felt like I was in some bizzaro bar, reminiscent of my early bar days (fake id days I should say).  

Sigh...where does an aging drinker go these day?  The Starlight Lounge?  The Gold Dust Lounge?  Anywhere with Lounge in the name!?
author: Brye L.

description: A real fireplace? Get out! This place probably works because it always gets so foggy in the sunset. When it's 80 degrees in the Castro but 60 degrees in the sunset, you have no problems walking into a cozy bar and kicking back with a beer by the fire. Like most of the local joints, there's not much that really stands out about this place, but I love the fact that you can walk across the street, grab some tacos, and walk back in to pair it with your cerveza. I don't know if I just never took advantage of it before or if it's something that you find more in SF, but I love the fact you can bring outside food into a lot of bars. It's really the best of both worlds.
author: Saunders C.

description: nice bar with a fireplace and good size pours on drinks
author: Priya K.

description:
Cheap drinks, really relaxed atmosphere, and cool bartenders.  I've had many a drink here, both just to stay, and as a one-for-the-road-before-MUNI-shows-up, and every time it's been pretty damned cool.  

My only complaints about this place are:  1.  The couch area is a great idea, but it can get pretty cramped in there by the fire.  Not too big a deal, but kind of annoying, and 2.  One time this place smelled a little like puke and nobody but me seemed to notice.  Maybe it was me, but that's a pretty distinct smell.
author: Patrick B.

description: fun and quirky place. decent drinks but nothing remarkable. solid 3 star local wine and booze bar. fun characters!!
author: Libra J.

description: My new favorite bar in the neighborhood. Super chill relaxed atmosphere, comfy and cozy, friendly people, AWESOME bartender. No frills, no nonsense, classic reliable neighborhood bar.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I like the Fireside. It doesn't smell like Yancy's does, musty and stale, the Jukebox is fantastic, anything and everything you could want, and the crowd is totally chill. I remember when this place was the Wishing Well with no beer on tap and old men at the bar all hours. 

Some guy wrote a review on here that has nothing to do with the bar, rather the patrons who get a little out of hand. Three words for you buddy, "Close your window"
author: David G.

description: A bar is a bar, but the Fireside is a party.  Yelpers took over the bar early on Saturday afternoon, and it was a very friendly affair.  No spilled beer smell here, it opened clean.  There were little bar tables all over the room, but joy of joys the centerpiece is THREE large curved couches surrounding the enormous-looking fireplace.  It felt like we were in someone's living room.  I thought, this would have been nice to know about in the rain and drizzle last month.  Ah, fog days approach, and I have this bar in my catalogue now!  The internet jukebox was tres cool -- Jill downloaded a tune -- you can play anything you want!  The bartender was Mr. Cool, too.
author: David D.

description:
We ended up going here bc we were in the mood for a chill, "old person" kinda place. Boy were we wrong. Apparently..Fireside is the poppin place on Friday nights in the inner sunset...haha. 

I actually thought it was a cool little place, small but there's as much seating as can possibly fit in a space that small. The drinks are cheap, the bartenders attentive, and you'll see a very ... mixed crowd. I've heard that during the week its much more chill, but on the weekends - look out for a large crowd and loud music. 

Note: while parking around 7th/irving is not ample during the day..at midnight on a Friday there is a ton of parking right outside.
author: Grace G.

description:
Classy dive bar?  Yes, this may  be it.  

I like this place because it's casual, and yet it's not the typical dive.  There is a fireplace/fire, with couches and tables around it for intimate conversation, and also other little tables scattered around, in addition to the typical long bar you see in such an establishment.  The staff is hot, (well one of the bartenders is, I was so focused on him, I didn't notice any of the other staff) and there is a jukebox that has a good selection, and plays good music (esp. since I picked the songs!).  

Been here 2 times, the first time on a weekend when it was packed but not in the way where you can't move through the room.  Last night, on a Tuesday night, every seat was taken but again, not overly packed.  

Good times.
author: Denise B.

description:
I used to come here when they first opened.  It was very cozy, they had a fireplace and some nice sofas.  Reminded me of some of those vacation houses in Tahoe that your friends own and you hang out at during the winter.  

Now it's super busy, and I haven't come by in years.  If you don't mind the crowd, check it out.  There's a crowd for a reason...
author: Dong T.

description:
Maybe it was an off night, but I got nothing out of my visit to Fireside.  The eponymous fire wasn't even lit!

One side of the bar was a bunch of old guys, and the other end was a pretty drunk group of young guys.  It's good to see a mix of clientele, but it seemed like the kind of place where regulars might get a bit territorial.

The seating area was just a mess of chairs and tables in random locations, and apparently no one was working except the bartender because empty glasses were all over the place.

There was a good selection of music, but it was up so loud there was no chance to carry on a conversation without shouting.

Maybe on a snowy winter day I'd go back in hopes of sitting near the fire, but that's not exactly likely, is it?
author: Zach P.

description:
Is there anything you can say bad about The Fireside?? I think not.

Between their great bartenders, heavy pours, cheap prices, and great crowd it's in a very small club of five star neighborhood bars. 

If you're looking for a foofy drink this might not be the spot... But if you're looking to hang out and have a drink you will be welcomed.
author: Joel H.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood bar.  The drinks are reasonable, the bartenders are always nice, and the comfy couches and fire adds a certain comfort that brings back fond memories of home.  Typically filled with a lot of folks that work at UCSF and other local Inner-Sunsettians, the crowd is usually as neighborly and quaint as the decor.
author: Shane C.

description:
This is the best place west of Stanyan St.

The bartenders (several of whom are owners) are somehow *always* friendly, even when it's extra busy on Thursday/Friday/Saturday nights.  They have a great selection of good booze and good beer, dog biscuits under the bar, a good jukebox (feel free to play it, it'll override the iPod that's hooked up to the stereo), and friendly regulars.  It's a mixed crowd that always gets along... there's no attitude on either side of the bar.

For sports and/or frat brothers, please continue down the street to Yancy's.  

The N stops in front of the place, and the 6/66/43/44/71 are all within a block or two.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Chimay, on tap!  and only $6!

Chill place to sip on suds and lounge.  We went for a walk in the park, which is really close by, at night afterwards.
author: Trix L.

description:
The Fireside Bar, former the Wishing Well, is a nice neighborhood bar in the Inner Sunset part of San Francisco. The bar is small with the majority of the place being taken up by the bar. The staff has always been friendly, so have the patrons. As one reviewer stated they have not minded if you bring food in from the local restaurants. Probably since they do not service any food. Due to the bar's size individual groups of more than 7 people may be difficult unless you are going to take over the whole bar. The jukebox is varied and fun with a major artist represented. Drinks are cheap but good. 

This is a low key place to relax and have some drinks and hang out with friends. Don't come expecting DJ's, dancing, and such. 

Chill out at the Fireside Bar.
author: Lance H.

description:
Looking for a bar to hang out with friends?  This is the spot!  Parking may be a bit tough, but the atmosphere is very chill.  This bar is not like an average neighborhood bar...but rather like a bar you would find in the Marina (but without the d-bags).  

They offer an updated electronic jukebox which accepts dollars as well as credit cards!  Just pop in some dough, and let the good times roll!  Also, the jukebox accepts txt msgs that will post on the screen!  Let the dude that selected eight N*Sync songs in a row on the box know how you really feel!

Tip 'o the day:  Drop the deuce at another spot before you hit up Fireside.  The toilets are clean, but the stalls are a bit low...unless you have some exhibitionist tendencies in you...
author: Daniel M.

description:
Fernet shots, Chimay beer on tap, an impromptu amateur mike-less rendition of "I Love Rock N' Roll", an unplanned conversation with a loner, the smallish men's room stalls (that may count as just one giant stall) and losing your temper as you listen to everyone else's shitty jukebox choices as you impatiently wait for yours. But seriously it's my kinda place.

Mostly touted as a locals' hang-out, the bar has personality. And it starts at the top with the owner Lisa who (during a down period in my life) won points with me by not throwing me out of the bar (I spent a late night there drunk as a bachelor and eating nothing but salt. Yup, salt.). As for the bar itself, the seating by the fireplace is simple and intimate. The general atmosphere is lively but not overwhelming. 

I often go there on weekends with friends. I sometimes just go there myself. This is a great spot in a good part of town.
author: Brian A.

description:
We all finally regrouped here after Power to the Peaceful. After a long trek the buzz was starting to wear off and we needed more drinks. 
A cozy bar with cheap beer. For some reason the bartender took a great liking to the"man" and hooked us up. The problem was that we were all ready very drunk. Craziness ensued, lots of spilled beer, party poppers and roaming puppies.
author: Douggers M.

description:
My date and I got tipsy for $15! Yes, that's right $15 (2 glasses of wine, 2 rum and cokes and a Chimay) 

How was this possible? Frankly, I have no idea. 
Cheap drinks, a warm fire and a hot date, one of the best weeknight, laid back excursions I have had in quite some time!
author: D H.

description:
Fireside was exactly what I was looking for after journeying over to Inner Sunset one Thursday night:

Not too crowded, not too empty.
Full bar + cheap (but good) wine selection.
Amusing decor - neon fireplace, framed pictures of antlers.
Laid back (but not vagrant) crowd.
author: Anna R.

description:
I like this place though it makes me feel like and booze hound.

They have my favorite import beer here and that's cool. The place is very chill. Like that. Whenever I'm here it's always super bright outside and I'm sitting at the bar, drinking my beer feeling like an alcoholic because I open my cell phone hoping one one my lame friends has txted me back and they haven't and it's not quite 4 PM and I'm going to order a second beer. 

I guess any bar could make you feel this way... but this is the bar that does it for me. 

Cheers!
author: Dustin H.

description: Been here a number of times; cozy ambience, sometimes with a cool movie projected without audio on the mounted big screen.  +1 for comping the soft drink with the assumption that it was for the designated driver; -1 for putting ice in the Fernet without asking me, after leaving the bar unattended for some 5+ minutes, a lifetime in nightlife parlance.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Could this really be the same place that I barely remember as the Wishing Well from 12 freaking years ago? No more scary drunks, no more gruff bartenders, no more vague smell of vomit.

Ordinarily, I'd say that all those thing made the Wishing Well worth coming to, but I have to admit that this place is totally relaxing and worth coming to in an entirely different way now.

It lost its divey-ness without sacrificing its soul, which is about as much as you could hope for.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I got a chance to stop by fireside last weekend and really enjoyed the atmosphere - low lighting, cute small tables, and good music selection from the bartender. 

It's the perfect lounge spot for a date or meeting up with a couple friends for a drink.  Not a rowdy crowd, not a fancy crowd, and no super loud music - just right for talking and catching up without the feeling that you should have put on a pound of makeup and stilettos before leaving the house. 

They have a couple nice tables by the windows, but if you can snag one of the tables in front of the fireplace, added bonus.  

And the best part... Drinks are amazingly cheap - I got a martini for $5.50 - and it wasn't happy hour!
author: Amy J.

description:
There's bars and then there's real bars, the Fireside is a real bar, especially during the day when you sit, relax, talk to Big Mario (Saturday thru Tuesday) and chat with fellow San Francisco natives. 

I used to frequent this establishment when it was the Wishing Well, the new owners did a great job of refurbishing the place.  A little too crowded for me on weekend nights, but then again, the  only time I really want to be in a crowded bar is when I am working it !

Drop on by, say hello to my buddy, Mario, have a cocktail or twelve and experience a real San Francisco bar.
author: Ray S.

description: I love this bar! Not only because the bartender is a hottie but also because it is a Pet Friendly Bar!!!!! The bartender was very friendly and he knows how to make the PERFECT AMF's!! I love the environment here everyone is very friendly .
author: Dena A.

description:
this is in category #3 of reviews for me - i.e. reviews of places near my (now one year old) condo... the go-to place for discriminating drinkers in the inner sunset.  not sure what that means.  i mean, if you're the go-to place for discriminating drinkers in, like, tribeca ... or west hollywood... i mean, that's Something... but being the go-to place in the inner sunset?  well, i guess it's better than 2nd place!

there is a fire.  there's usually a couple dogs.  normally a place to sit either at the bar or one of the tables by the door or the fire-thing. also often has a couple locals so blitzed that they can hardly stumble out the door but don't let that put you off.  it's a very nice, clean, classy spot to grab a drink with some pals right on irving.  close to all the restaurants.  has the advantage of not attracting huge groups of college kids nor collecting a fraternity party type atmosphere.  small groups in here only.  chatting about stuff by the fire.
author: dan h.

description: Came in here last night after dinner with a friends parents. We were looking for a nice warm place were we could grab a drink and stay out of the rain, and while this fit the bill, it only met our requirements bare bones. I have never, never ever been in a bar with music so loud that it is next to impossible to hold a conversation, that is aside from bars where dancing is involved. But no, no dancing here, just impossibly loud music. The drinks we ordered were fine, but I doubt we'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Allyson S.

description:
cozy dive bar and they actually have a fireplace. nice. it was a nice venue to have a nice saturday afternoon potluck. special thanks to our very own cindy k for setting up such a nice potluck, you rock. 

chimay on tap.
fat tire on tap.

CHIMAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Euge L.

description: Ew.  I didn't like this place at all.  So much so, that Tal K. and I didn't even finish our drinks before heading over to Mucky Duck.  The people were, hmm, I don't even know how to describe them.  I felt like it was a secret boys club or something that started at 9 a.m. and sadly, continued on through the night.  I don't get the bar.  I don't get the glowing fireplace.  Are you a sports bar or a lounge?  I felt like I was in a bad Miami Vice episode.  I was just hoping Crokett and Tubbs would show up to relieve us from the horrible plot and reveal the secret subplot.
author: Rachel C.

description:
a great place but too dang LOUD. forget about convo but enjoy the fair-priced potent libations. the fireplace is nice and cozy. I had wanted to go to Yancy's but my friend insisted we come here instead and I'm glad we did. this was where she and her a-hole bf broke up so she has a soft spot in her heart for the Fireside. be warned, there are fuglies aplenty but also fine lookers here & there, present company included. couldn't really call this a hook-up bar . . .

the ladies' room near the end of the night ? I carry Clorox wipes in my purse for just such places (shut up). but I know I will be back here sooner rather than later
author: Prima D.

description:
always have a great time here.  this is mine and my girl bruna's go to place for catching up and drinking too  much jameson.
bartenders have always been friendly and funny, which is a major plus.  always a pretty good crowd, too!
author: Vanessa M.

description: How awesome was it that we were able to have a POTLUCK here??! If you could imagine, Grace brought a fabulous chocolate fountain, and there it was, chocolate flowing next to the jukebox! It was the perfect space. Mario, the bartender, was so nice and made all of us feel right at home. Drinks were inexpensive too. We took over most of the space, but there were plenty of seats and tables. It was a great time had by all. Fireside is a great bar with that neighborhood-y vibe where everyone knows your name.
author: Connie C.

description: Great alternative to Yancy's across the street. They take credit cards and the drinks are cheaper. Enough said!!
author: Dennis L.

description: Pretty cool bar/lounge in the Sunset. I've been there a couple of times and always enjoyed it. As it's name suggests, it's got a big fireplace in the middle of the bar, and and it also has plenty of seating. The drinks are reasonably priced, and the bartenders are friendly: cool and low-key place to unwind and catch up with your friends over a few drinks.
author: David S.

description: I came here on a whim with a friend the other night and was pleasantly surprised. He told me that it was more of a "chill" place and that it wouldn't be too crowded......or so he thought. We walked in and were easily able to find a seat at the bar. Not 30 minutes later, the place was packed! The bartender was super attentive, didn't make anyone wait more than a couple minutes to get a drink and was great at refilling drinks when we were running low/empty. The busboy however, was a little too quick at cleaning out glasses that were "empty." I had maybe a sip or two left of beer in my glass and he takes it, moves it down the bar where the rest of the empty glasses were, and moved on. I immediately took my glass back and finished my beer before it was gone forever. I paid for a full glass of beer and damnit I'm going to drink it all!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Could Fireside Bar be any cooler?  They were nice enough to help us out with holding the make-up YelPotluck.  Manager Lisa is very personable and accommodating.  She arranged for bartender Mario to come and set up a table for our Saturday event.  Though Mario was late... he was totally chill when Yelpers brought their foodstuffs for the potluck, and leading me to the power outlet on which to plug my now infamous Chocolate Fountain.  (booyah!)  They never charged us so long as we helped them out by buying drinks.  
They have a great selection of beers--from your standard long-neck bottled Coronas with lime, to your Chimay served in your own pimp-cup.  The mixed drinks are not watered down--had the right amount of ice.  All drinks were awesomely-reasonably priced.  They have a jukebox that takes credit cards--containing a grand selection of old and contemporary songs.  The atmosphere is very chill and could be nicely intimate for your group.
Will definitely come here for happy hours and future YelPotlucks!
author: Grace M.

description: Dogs are allowed in this bar. The furry woof woof kind.
author: Teddy B.

description: Nice quiet neighborhood bar. Cheap drinks, cozy, bartender was friendly. Won't be my go-to spot but its a good option for a quieter, intimate night for drinks.
author: Cori W.

description: I yelled "TIMBER!!" when I looked across the room to see a tall wasted dude go blank eyed and fall flat on his face. It was about 3 in the afternoon and I thought - how'd this dude get so fucked up so early? Then, I knew it was time for me to leave even though the fireplace was so damn cozy and cute. I do suggest you try this bar, particularly if you are looking for a spot that opens early (I think 1pm) in the Sunset. Just be weary of falling bodies.
author: Amy E.

description: nice cozy place that's not crowded or noisy. people hang out here are friendly and reasonable. love, love, love :)
author: Frost L.

description: I spent many a fine day in the Wishing Well, and I miss it. I guess it's a little more swanky now, and probably appeals to a younger, more prissy crowd. You know, the kind of people who don't hang out in bars at breakfast time.
author: Megan W.

description:
so i actually went during the day. i dont usually go to the bars in the afternoon, but i needed the internet, and thats where the cafe across the street pointed me to... fireside bar. i was surprised to see so many people there. some chilling at the bar laughing and talking. others, like me with a laptop

at 4pm i was sitting at the bar writing my paper with a beer in hand. definitely a different experience.

so if you need to.. there's wifi and outlets.
author: Natalie B.

description: For some reason, even though I can be such a miser, put me in a suitably low lit room with a good jukebox and drinks and I might just spend away if no-one else is taking care of the tunes.  Sure this isn't the trendiest place, or even the best deal (fairly smallish martinis, normal prices for SF, which means pretty high), but on a slower night the comfortable atmosphere, nice bartenders, and chatter of people who are clearly friends and regulars is perfect for a serene time with your mate/mates.  Warning, if you fall under the spell of playing any goofy music you want, along with the safe womb-like atmosphere, you might just have too many drinks for your own good...
author: GIR ..

description: Fireside quickly moved to the top of my list of local haunts after moving to the neighborhood.  On walking in, the interior is just fabulous, clean, cozy and hip... with a fireplace!  The crowd is usually a really broad mix of ages and styles and always exceptionally friendly.  It helps that the bartenders and owners are engaging and mix the crowd as well as they mix the drinks.  There is an internet jukebox but the bartenders often play from the iPod playlists.  I've heard that there is even free WiFi but I haven't had a chance to crack open the laptop inside.
author: Jack S.

description: A bargain. Great music, friendly bartender who will THROW DOWN the misbehavin' drunks. Just the right amout of creepy regulars (seriously, i like to get a little bit tipsy and try and converse with them) ALL the neighborhood food service employee's hit this place up after work, an excellent sign
author: B.dot P.

description:
A pretty clean bar, nowadays.  Very cozy, with good seating and a fairly good beer selection.  This is not a bar that attracts locals (as far as I can tell) but is a good, intimate place to take a date.  The fireplace is a nice touch, but seems a bit chintzy.  In any case, the sofas and chairs offer a different touch than most seating in Sunset bars.

The bar does not have any diversions besides the fireplace (although I have heard there will be a pool table installed soon).  The jukebox is entirely typical, no surprises.

This bar, like many in the Sunset, suffers from being unfocused.  It isn't trendy enough to be a draw to people outside the Sunset, but also isn't friendly enough to locals to be a regular's bar.  In all, a good place for a date, but not the kind of place you would want to spend time in every week.
author: John B.

description:
A lounge? A wine bar? Are you kidding me, Yelp? The Fireside Bar is basically a step up from a dive bar. With Chimay on tap you could call it a premium dive bar. Very dog friendly, with treats behind the bar for your pooch, and a laid back bartender who serves up the Chimay with a discount, "because it's too expensive." When I asked if I could get a half pint of beer, he replied, "I'll serve you any size you'd like." When asked for chips, the answer was "I'll see what I can dig up, the night crew eats it all up." Tossed a couple of bags our way for free. Free chips, free dog treats, a fireplace, Guinness on tap along with a nice Butte Porter, the Chimay and a few more wine selections than the norm. A trio of female regulars were drunk at 2pm and singing Irish songs; by some incredible stroke of divine providence they were in tune and not half bad. 
I'm not saying I'd drive over from Oakland to come here, but if you are in the hood this is a nice relaxing place to be, with a retro feel and some good local color/ people watching opportunities. With an older crowd and no frat rat types in evidence, it's a lot less grating and much more alt/interesting than Yancy's. Also, the N Judah stops right in front, so it's a good place to get a respite from the often brutal Inner Sunset micro-climate. The place is old but doesn't smell and looks clean. I haven't worked up the nerve to try the bathroom yet, I'll let you know. SF could use more dog friendly and unpretentious bars like this one.
author: tess s.

description: Very relaxed atmosphere, and a good place to grab a casual drink with a friend or a first date.  Decent selection of beers on tap and friendly service.  Restroom is somewhat comparable to a Chevron station.  The fireplace is a nice touch, but note this place is cash only.
author: Geoff K.

description: The last time I was here, the bartenders kept making mistakes and then giving us free drinks to make up for it.  Drinks are cheap here anyway, so no one was complaining.  Plus, "mistakes" were often upgrades.  (e.g. Gave me a shot of Greygoose when I'd asked for a greyhound.)  Only downside that night was the alternating Jimi Hendrix & Bob Dylan theme music ALL NIGHT long.  Pretty soon though, we were all too drunk to care.  Maybe that was the biggest mistake of all.
author: Ravena F.

description: Nice little hang out. Miss the old days when it was a DIVE. Like the improvements and the bartenders are friendly. Good place to start out if you want to get started for drinks.
author: J A.

description: AWESOME place for a not so quiet night with either your friends or significant other........Ive only been there about three times and the first time I was already Buzzin so much that the noise didn't impair my conversations at all......The jukebox has a great selection, you have a multitude of beers to choose from and as the name would suggest they have a fire!!! No shit a for real, live in your face will burn your butt toasty fire.
author: Shaunna K.

description: This is a great place to just chill out, have some drinks, and catch up with your friends.  Staff is awesome.  The prices are decent.  I like the mojitos.  They have a crazy futuristic jukebox that looks like a giant cell phone mounted on the back wall.  Be forewarned if you are allergic to dogs as sometimes there are dogs hanging out in the bar but I think they are short haired.  But it's usually dark so I can't be totally sure.  Good vibe - not a seedy pick up joint.  Decor is like classy dive.  It's never too packed that you can't get a drink.  It's never too loud that you can't hear the person next to you.  3.5/5.0
author: Nat L.

description: Steve-E Rules! Who doesn't like a fireplace. Nice beer selection. Another good date spot.
author: nic c.

description: They weren't joking about the fireside name. It's warm right when you enter. The people who work here are friendly and it's a nice, small spot to hang out and drink with friends. They have a juke box that looks like a super sized iPod. Went here after Outside Lands and there's good places to eat that are walking distance.
author: Janice F.

description: venturin' out to sunset...fireside bar to end the night....sip, gulp, shoot 'n' chill....good vibes from interior 'n' staff.....local no frill bar...relaxin' in cozy atmosphere....drink of tequila 'n' beers.....friendly to patrons 'n' others alike.....pricing moderate/high....remembering $five plus total after tip for beers....
author: Hen A.

description: I love this place!!  It's like a classy dive bar, it's kinda small with a little fire, but it's cute and has a romatic feel.  The drinks are strong and the neighboorhood rocks, what more do you want?
author: Anastasia N.

description: This bar was only about 5 min. away from me and i had never stepped foot in here until some friends brought me here.  Let's just say i started to frequent this bar and i am now a huge fan.  The atmosphere is low key, the staff is super nice and the prices are good.
author: Michelle M.

description: Great, cozy, warm, inviting but cash only. Good place for chatting with friends around the fire (yes there is really a fire place). The bartenders are friendly and attentive. Definitely a great place to spend slower, intimate bar evenings as opposed to wasted, slap happy disco night club evenings.
author: Snora E.

description: Fireside is the ideal local hangout in the UCSF/Irving area.  They have a full bar and Guinness on tap (what else do you need to know?).  It could get a bit little noisy once in awhile, but it's all in the name of fun.  People and staff are friendly, and who can argue against a fireplace?  In fact, Fireside demonstrates that all bars would do well with a fireplace.
author: Rick K.

description: My little brother dragged to this place and I honestly did not enjoy one bit of it....
author: Jeremy N.

description: This chilled out bar is a perfect spot to get up close to that sweet thang you been eyeing. They've got a fireplace, but if you want to sit next to it, you best show up before the crowds do, cuz only a few chairs are near the fire.  Otherwise, this place is a great, small neighborhood bar filled with locals.
author: Jon F.

description: So i heard that this was supposed to be a dive bar....i guess by dive bar they mean that there aren't a ton of plasma screens all over the walls because otherwise, this is a pretty normal bar.  The crowd is relatively mellow and the bartenders are fast and friendly.  Great bar for the Irving street crowd.
author: Robert R.

description: met a friend here for drinks. super chill spot. there is actually a fireplace that you can sit around. not too crowded. another nice option for a neighborhood bar if you want something a little bit more low key.
author: Linda N.

description: Love the fireplace.  Nice bar, drinks were good, bartenders' friendly, a good place to stop in when bar hopping in the area, not sustainable as a destination in its self.
author: Julia W.

description:
LUV IT!

been coming here for 3.5 years now.  steve-o is awesome!  drinks are great, fabulous ambiance, great music.  pet some dogs, chat up some older regulars.

bring a couple of your friends, grab some food and come on in!  order a drink, munch down, and hang out.  the best place to enjoy someone else's company.  not much to distract you here so come here on your second date...or after your first...
author: gail g.

description: I love this cozy little bar. They have a great jukebox and a very romantic fireplace area. The place smells of sweatsocks and beer, but what pub doesn't? Go with the mixed drinks or one of the many brews on tap. Wine is not a good options here... :)
author: Kath R.

description: The fireside is a nice neighborhood bar that is usually fairly quiet.  Accordingly, it is a great place to hang out, enjoy a glass of wine, and have nice conversation with a girlfriend, a date, a good friend, etc.  when you want to be out, but want to avoid the normal scenes.  Oh, and the staff here is excellent.
author: Matthew H.

description: Maybe it was an off night (Tuesday), but this place was super dead and the namesake fire was not lit.  Boring, empty, and not-so-great music (except one Rancid song).  Pabst on tap is cool, but come on...
author: Eric S.

description: Friendly bartenders and patrons.... but it was a bit loud and not conducive for a conversation with people you haven't spoken to in a while.  I had a cosmo (ok, shoot me but didn't know what to order) and the vodka stoli was the smoothest I've ever had.  The crowd was diverse and happy!  I would come back for the friendly atmosphere and drinks.
author: Noreen M.

description: First: Chimay on tap. Just for that the place deserves respect. My opinion is that a trappist beer should be kept in bottles to perfect the fermentation process, not in kegs but...it is good, no word on that. Second: the bartender is great! He offered me a Duvel since we started chatting about the Chimay on tap, we chatted a lot about ales and eventually he got me drunk with shots. It was probably the friendliest pub experience I had in SF so far. Third: I don't remember, I was drunk.
author: Dario B.

description: The FIRE part is just a gimmick to get you in the door.  The FIRE doesn't add to the experience because it's so small and blocked by three big couches.  I had a pleasant evening but didn't enjoy the loud music in such a small space.  It's an OK bar.
author: Patrick A.

description: I moved to san francisco's inner sunset in february 2006, President's day to be exact. I unpack a box or two and decided it's time to settle into my new 'hood and find my local dive. I walk down to the Fireside Bar and join one other patron at the bar. I buy a beer (PBR draft) and the bartender welcomes me to the neighborhood with a shot of tequila. Needless to say, I feel right at home.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
i love a place with nice booth seating. it doesn't even have to be super fancy, quilted leather with gold buttons either. just something soft to relax on after bouncing around from bar to bar, swerving drunkenly through traffic on my bike. this is a nice, relaxing place to bring the night to a close. well, on a weekday, that is. and that's just the sort of way i need to end my weeknights in my old age. no more of this partying until 3 a.m., swinging from the rafters anymore, and waking up at 6.

before even entering, i was drawn to the front door. the half-door entrance always reminds me of my early days, knee-high to a grasshopper, trapped within the daycare center. they always had these doors. and i was always too small to see over them, but knew people were watching me. now that i'm significantly bigger, these doors pose no threat to me, so i look upon them fondly - like an old, conquered foe.

the crowd looked a little beaten down, but then again this was a tuesday night. i probably shouldn't have even been in a bar. that wasn't very responsible of me. but they have PBR on tap, and this close to payday, that's a good thing. and then there's the soft booth seating..
author: Jeremiah W.

description: Chanced upon this place when I finally decided to explore (ie: bar hop) this part of town.  I wanted to like this place so much but it was like I was in two bars at once.  I liked the firelit, ambiance rich part of it; I wanted to purge this better half of the TVs-against-the-wall bar.  Not that I have anything against TVs in bars, but here, they seemed out of place.  Four stars, though, for a real fireplace.
author: Helen C.

description: Each time I have come to Fireside, it has been to have just a beer on my way home.  Each time I have come here, I have walked away with new friends and pretty intoxicated.  I think last night I spent $10 and hung out with locals for several hours, and ended up having at least 8 drinks.  The locals and bartenders are awesome, super friendly and welcome new faces (which is really rare for a SF bar from what I have seen) and also a lot of fun to talk to.  This place guarantees a particular crowd certain nights of the week, but I have come to love each of them.  Sorry for sounding so smooshie - thats just me for you.
author: Meredith N.

description: Really dark, reasonably priced drinks, nice/80's looking fireplace, large selection of tunes on the electronic juke box.
author: Misha F.

description: The sweet bartender lady makes a fabulous mojito. I'm not typically a mojito drinker, but I get 'em here.
author: riz n.

description: I love Fireside for the warmth both the fireplace and plentiful beers on tap give me. I also love Fireside for being dog-friendly (including treats behind the bar) and cute-guy friendly (including treats behind the bar).
author: Anne Q.

description: this place is tiny and cozy, and safe! drinks are cheap and plenty of parking outside. i recommend sitting at the window, it's small but we were able to seat six. or if you can, sit by the fireplace.
author: Stella C.

description: This bar has really grown on me. It's a bit on the small side, but that can't be helped. If you're looking for a cozy place, with a fire, to chat with a few friends, this is the place. The N-Judah stops right out front. You're in the middle of inner Sunset close to several good eateries.  The bartenders are cool and so is the clientele. Being a Chimay lover, I usually can't resist the white Chimay on tap.If you find yourself riding the Muni into work and suddenly decide you don't want to work in the office, or work sober, jump off and hop in for a few cold ones. They have wireless.
author: Rich M.

description: Warm and cozy are your first impressions. Not so warm and cozy when it's packed on a weekend night. Great spot for a lil' get together on a weekday night or early weekend evening. Bartenders and patrons are real cool.
author: Leroid D.

description: Nice and warm on a winter's day.  I do miss the dive-y aspect of the Wishing Well, but the floors are much cleaner and the drunks don't live here all the time anymore...  that's a little sad, but --  nice place for a warm hands/cold drink.
author: .Hazel T.

description: A nice cozy bar with upbeat music! Its usually pretty packed during the weekend due to its size, but a nice low profile place to bang out at. The first time I came here, it seemed a bit dark. But I guess it set a nice tone, especially with the fire blazing in the background. Too bad only a select few can sit by the small fireside.
author: Andrew W.

description: Good drinks, friendly bartender, low-key atmosphere, fire, cozy, and normal everyday people. I like it.
author: S. P.

description: good bar, but then again i rarely frequent here at night. it's typically in my "daytime" drinking unemployed phase...hey, they got wifi - so getting sloshed while sending out resumes is multi-tasking at it's fullest?! Mario is a great bartender too, by the way.
author: James J.

description:
steve is the best bartender in the world! he's a friend and a confidant... i will share a whisky with him any day of the week!

i tend to bring my friends there for a nightcap and forget to pay my tab as i stumble to hail a cab...

he understands and never holds a grudge... we're cool like that!
author: Sam P.

description:
i went here for the first time last night as a friend i were wandering around the inner sunset looking for a place to have just one drink for the night. being in the mood to chat, we were hoping to avoid someplace crowded or loud.

we walked up to the lovely front door, which is a split door, to let in the fresh breeze. a few small tables surrounded the fireplace and we were able to each get a whiskey sour for $4.50!! how's that? it was the drink special of the night. 

the ambiance was definitely nice and i will give them kudos for actually having a decent bar bathroom (i noted someone else's review mentioned there actually being toilet paper, and i can report that yes, there was also plenty when i went last night.)

drink was good, the crowd was incredibly mellow and we were able to have a nice time.

the only draw backs were thus: random tvs that detracted from the ambiance, and a strange music mix. i would have expected something that added to the ambiance -- but it was this eclectic mix of hits and hard rock, which didn't seem to work.

i'll definitely be back --esp. since it's in between me and a friend that lives in glen park, and we can take the same bus there.
author: Carla B.

description: great interior, a place you actually want to stick around and have a few drinks at. The fireplace is a bit of a gimmick so better pick one of the little tables in the rest of the place. Serves Chimay which is a big plus. Downside was extremely slow service the last time I visited. Will not count it out though...
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
eh..
and fuck yeah, i'm from the mission.
when the bartender tells you that is his preferred stomping grounds...well you gotta wonder.

two stars 'cause my drink was free...
author: Zoe s.

description: We decided to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday here last Saturday, and had a great time. If you are looking for an unpretentious, laid back place to grab a drink in the Inner Sunset, this is a good choice. There were probably 20 or so people that stopped by for the birthday, and although not everyone got to sit down, it didn't feel overly crowded. Prices are reasonable (beers on tap were $4.50, i think) and the staff is great. They even provided extra napkins for us when we served the birthday cake. In fact, we liked it so much we are going back again tonight!
author: Naomi F.

description: I dont' know why the crowds aren't bigger here. It's clean, has modern decor, a cozy fireplace and friendly bartenders. Oh wait, I just answered my question. It's in the SUNSET.  My bad!
author: Laurie A.

description: This is my neighborhood date spot. It's nice and cozy, good drinks and very dark and romantic in a casual way.
author: Karen T.

description: I really liked this place because it was cozy and a little eclectic.  The -1 star is because it is a cash only bar.  I'm one of those people who rarely ever has cash on me so thank goodness the boyfriend was there or I would've been outta luck!  The drinks, however, where really inexpensive and the crowd was pretty chill.  They allow dogs in the bar too and really, any place that allows dogs automatically gets at least 3 stars, right?!?!
author: Vanessa K.

description: 4 stars for a neighborhood dive-y type bar. The environment is charming. I like sitting in the window seats. The barman is always friendly and generous with the dog treats (for my dog, not me). If you're out walking your dog and want a beer, this is your place.
author: Alice M.

description: I like this bar, the bartenders, and the crowd. The window seats & the fireplace are really nice. It's a cozy feel-- good neighborhood bar.
author: Heather M.

description: Laidback, cozy little bar.... I've always felt like it was a great place to meet friends and talk, but still be 'in the scene." It's a nice walk from the neighborhood, but right on the train line. Either way, it's a great stop for a good drink!
author: Jen T.

description: Good neighborhood bar...Fireplace is warm and homey and though it is hard to get near, you can see it from everywhere...Big screen TV's let you sneak in that sports game while talking to that special someone...friendly bartenders...good mix of Locals, UCSF students, etc...
author: James H.

description: Best behind the bar snacks in town! No cats! And a water-bowl in the back.  But really makes a bar are the folks who go there. A special warm toast to my bar fly pals: Rodney, Fin and Blanca, May your tails always wag! See you there soon. OOOOOOWWWWWWWOOOO!
author: Ichiban H.

description: The fire place looks good but as the minutes tick by the scarf comes off the sleeves roll up, uncomfortable fidgetting, sweat balls on your upper lip then a mad dash away from the fire just too hot for me so I grab my beverage (which by the way  took about 5 or 10 minutes to recieve except  the night I set with the bartenders buddy) then I go to the newish soft corner booths near the window there I can blankly stare at the passer bys contemplating my next sip of guiness, a very good guiness I live near by so I walk by this place alot and it looks like it gets pretty crowded I like it quiet for a nice before dinner drink you must try. Prices are good service not too good. The bathroom was clean when I went in
author: lloyd K.

description: As a local, I have been finding myself choosing this bar over Yancy's across the street more and more.  Don't get me wrong Yancy's is great, but when it just gets too packed with the local college folk, head over to Fireside for a little quieter ambiance, great drinks, or if you just ran out of cash and only have plastic b/c this place accepts credit cards.  Cheers.
author: Anthony D.

description: My first bar in my new Sunset neighborhood - just grabbed a few drinks on a Friday night. A Patti-Smith-looking bartender was very cool and funny (and not necessarily in that order). I'm not a friend of the digital jukebox - in fact they terrify me, but you can't win them all. It was 5 bucks for 12 or so plays is the cheapest you can do. I put in a little Dave Brubeck into my playlist to keep things pumping on a Friday night...yea, no one really cares what music you choose, especially if it's jazz. But I like to believe everyone's night was made by those 12 choices I made. The atmosphere was great - cozy, relaxed. Not too crowded and there was delicious chimay on tap. And more importantly, no yuppies, which is good as I'm incapable of having a good time if I'm within 50 yards of them.
author: Jared M.

description: Great bar with an awesome atmosphere.  You're treated like friend whether it's your first time or if you're a regular.
author: JP B.

description: it is what it is - best bar in the inner sunset, with a slightly lower level of agro-testosterone. nice bartenders who will remember you when you come back.
author: Jessica C.

description: i wish fireside were closer to where i live so i could go there more often. it was the perfect place to have a hot toddie on this bizarrely rainy and humid sunday night. i fought my desire to take a nap on the couches in front of the fire for fear that i would never leave.
author: julia r.

description: This hole in the wall is great for a weeknight - if you live in the area.  I haven't been back since I moved - so I guess that is a negative attestation to the place. But, I have to give them props for finally remodeling it.
author: sarah e.

description: my pal and i hit fireside were it was less crowded at tipoff than yancy's.  the bartender rules and gets out the drinks like no one's business.  thank you sir.  the projector screen was a little wonky because it was on zoom, but not so horrible that it mared the viewing experience.  we had a couple kids in "we believe" tees.  felt kinda like being at the game.  the place started to get crowd int eh 1st quarter but i was parked nicely at my table.  they have good ventalation unlike the aforementioned yancy's.  sure, they don't have the fancy flat screens up, but the service and air quality are steller.
author: Sharlene C.

description: definitely my top pick for the irving bars, quite cozy with a decent atmosphere. if you're out in the ave's definitely a place to hit up if you just want to catch a drink and chill.
author: Syonora A.

description: when i picture a place called fireside i picture... i don't know. old school log cabin or ski lodge type surroundings. not a disco fireplace.  DISCO!  it kind of doesn't work for me. it might work for you but the only sparkle and flickering i want to see in close relation to a fireplace should be coming OUT of a fireplace, not dancing around it. why should a fireplace compete with cheesy late 90s disco block lights?
author: ms.kiki g.

description: Cozy bar, fine place to chill with friends. Who cares about the ambience, or the food, or the crowd mix. Give me a place where I can get a beer for less than $5 and I'm happy.
author: A. T.

description: I've only been here a few times but everytime I go I have a great time... Cool mood and  average prices. It's never gotten so busy that I couldn't grab a table and it usually doens't take more than a few minutes to get a drink (plus they pour them kind of stifff).  Over-all just a cool place to sit back and enjoy the night.
author: JOHN L.

description: When the Wishing Well transformed into The Fireside, they took a full-time dive-y bar and made it safe for the people who used to be afraid to go in there. The draft selection has improved, though, and during daylight hours, the clientele is virtually unchanged from before (and Bartender Mario still presides most afternoons). As yup watering holes go, even at night, this place is actually pretty okay. It's comfortable, not too expensive, neither too bright nor too dark. Plus, Terry's Lodge is too far to walk home from after a few. Wish they still had the old jukebox, though....
author: Steve F.
